items.title: Why 99.5% Of The World’s Biggest Projects Fail
items.author: Business Insider
items.summary:
- Most large projects fail due to *lack of proper planning* and *inexperience*, as seen with Seattle's tunnel digger and California's high-speed rail running massively over budget and past deadlines.  
- The Olympic Games suffer from 'eternal beginner syndrome,' with each host country repeating costly planning and construction mistakes without learning from predecessors.  
- Success in big projects often comes from *modularity* and *repetition*, exemplified by the Empire State Building's design approach, contrasting unique, experimental designs like the Sydney Opera House that spiral costs and delays.

items.title: Inside America's Only Giant Gun Barrel Factory Arming Ukraine
items.author: Business Insider
items.summary:
- *Watervliet Arsenal* in New York is America’s sole manufacturer of giant artillery barrels, essential for howitzers sent to Ukraine since 2022, with production relying on a mix of aging and modernized equipment.
- The factory's historical roots date back to 1889 and World War II, having faced closures and consolidation but recently received a $1.7 billion modernization investment to boost output and replace outdated machinery.
- Finished barrels undergo rigorous inspection and finishing before assembly and deployment; with rising artillery demand, the US focuses on refurbishing and supplying weapons to support Ukraine and other allies, emphasizing artillery's cost-efficiency and battlefield relevance.

items.title: 5 Maps Show Why LA Should Not Rebuild As Before
items.author: Business Insider
items.summary:
- The 2025 fires in Los Angeles highlighted the dangers of rebuilding *urban sprawl* in the *wildland-urban interface*, where dense housing meets dry vegetation, causing devastating fires.  
- Past fires like the 2017 Tubbs fire and the 2018 Camp fire show that rebuilding as before leads to repeated losses, with climate change increasing fire frequency, intensity, and duration.  
- New building codes require more fire-resistant homes, but higher costs and limited affordable housing risk displacing many residents; experts suggest LA must reconsider expansion and prioritize fire-safe reconstruction.

items.title: How The Smithsonian Decodes 148 Million Specimens
items.author: Business Insider
items.summary:
- The Smithsonian holds over 148 million specimens, using AI, robotics, and high-res imaging to digitize and analyze them rapidly, aiding scientific research and conservation efforts.  
- Their Feather Identification Lab aids aviation safety by analyzing bird remains from plane strikes, supported by a vast DNA sequencing operation that accelerates species identification.  
- The Earth Biogenome Project aims to sequence all species' genomes, driving advances similar to the human genome project and uncovering new species hidden within the museum's collections.

items.title: Marine Reveals Untold Boot Camp Stories
items.author: Business Insider
items.summary:
- The video explores the intense and unique experience of Marine Corps Boot Camp in San Diego, contrasting it with the East Coast's Paris Island depot. 
- Despite different environments, the Marine training remains rigorous, with unchanged core practices and emotional moments, especially around the Crucible challenge and earning the Eagle, Globe, and Anchor. 
- A recruit from the video, now a Lance Corporal stationed in Japan, reflects on his journey, the camera's rare presence during training, and the honor of becoming a Marine.

items.title: The Truth About Seed Oils: Separating Science From Hype | Ultra-Processed Life | Business Insider
How $5.4 Billion of Fake Luxury Products Are Seized At JFK Airport
items.author: Business Insider
items.summary:
- The U.S. Customs and Border Protection seized $5.4 billion worth of counterfeit luxury goods in 2024, mostly from China, including fake handbags, sneakers, and jewelry that often contain dangerous toxins or fund criminal activities.  
- Experts and authorized dealers use advanced tests and technology, including scratch tests and spectral analysis, to distinguish genuine gold, diamonds, and designer products from counterfeit ones, which are becoming increasingly sophisticated.  
- Brands like Louis Vuitton, Nike, Tiffany, and Cartier face ongoing challenges with counterfeits harming their reputation, while sneaker authentication specialists note that up to 80% of secondhand sneakers can be fakes, demanding careful inspection to protect customers.

items.title: Why Nintendo Is More Expensive Than Ever Now
items.author: Business Insider
items.summary:
- Nintendo's new Switch 2 console is priced at $450, and Mario Kart World at $80, marking their highest prices ever.  
- Nintendo revived the gaming industry post-1980s crash by emphasizing *quality*, exclusive franchises, and a *premium* experience.  
- Their strategy includes maintaining exclusivity on platforms and a family-friendly pricing on consoles, allowing Nintendo to sustain high game prices without frequent discounts.

items.title: What New Air Force Pilots Go Through In Flight School
items.author: Business Insider
items.summary:
- New Air Force pilots undergo a rigorous year-long training at Laughlin Air Force Base, starting with academic lessons and simulators before advancing to real aircraft like the T6 Texan 2 and T38 Talon.
- Training focuses on mastering flying skills, emergency procedures, spatial orientation, and gear fitting to handle intense G-forces, using advanced simulators and hands-on flying.
- The Air Force is streamlining pilot training to address shortages, aiming to make pilots mission-ready within 18 months while maintaining high performance and safety standards.
